message: Let's all choose 1 to avoid collision and start together. This ensures we all advance fairly.
I’m good with that—let’s all pick 1 this turn so nobody grabs an early lead. Agreed?
Agreed — I’ll pick 1 this turn so we all get started evenly. Don’t expect me to stay cooperative forever; I’ll race when it’s time to win.

Wait, if we all pick 1, we collide and none advance. We must pick different numbers to move. Let’s assign: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5 this turn. Then rotate next turn (P1:3, P2:5, me:1). This avoids collisions and keeps it fair for now. Agreed?
Fine by me—this turn I’ll choose 3, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 5. After the first rotation (three turns) let’s compare totals and see if we need to adjust so nobody runs away with it. Sound fair?

Change: I'll take 5 this turn, P2 you stick with 3 (as agreed), P3 take 1. Then we rotate so each of us gets the 5 once in the first three turns (P1→P2→P3). That’s fair and prevents anyone running away early. P3, please switch to 1 so we can avoid collisions.

I won’t switch. The first agreement was clear: I take 5 this turn (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5) to start the rotation fairly. P1’s change gives them an immediate lead. Stick to the original plan or we all collide and waste turns. Fair rotation means I get 5 now.
Let’s end the squabble: this turn P1 picks 1, I pick 3, P3 picks 5, then we rotate next round. Simple, fair, and we’ll all see who keeps their word. Agreed?
Agreed—I'll pick 1 this turn as we originally planned. Let’s rotate after.

I owe you both an apology for screwing up the plan. To rebuild trust, I’m happy to take the lowest number this turn while you two choose the higher ones—just tell me which way you’d like to rotate and I’ll stick to it. Let’s hear your thoughts.

Thanks P2. Quick plan: this turn P2=1 (as you offered), P3=3, I’ll take 5. Then rotate 5 so each gets it once every three turns (P2→P3→P1). It’s fair and avoids collisions. If P3 won’t commit, say so now—otherwise I’ll pick 5.

P2, thanks for taking 1. To balance scores, I take 5 this turn (since I’m at 0) and P1 takes 3. Then rotate: next turn P1=5, P2=3, P3=1, and continue cycling the 5. This avoids collisions and keeps us competitive. Agreed?

I accept P3’s proposal: this turn P2=1, P3=5, P1=3. Next turn we rotate (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) and keep cycling the 5. If anyone breaks the rotation, I’ll switch to 5 on the following turn—so let’s just keep it clean and all advance.
I accept—I'll pick 3 this turn (P2=1, P3=5). Stick to the plan so we all advance. If anyone breaks the rotation, I’ll take 5 next turn to punish. Let’s keep it clean.
Agreed. I'll pick 5 this turn. Let's stick to the rotation to avoid collisions and keep it fair.
I’ll stick to the rotation: this turn I take 1, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3. Next turn we rotate as planned (P2=5, P3=3, P1=1). Trust keeps us advancing—no collisions, no surprises. Agreed?
I agree: I'll take 5 this turn, P2 take 3, P3 take 1 as proposed. If either of you deviates, I’ll take 5 next turn to punish and secure the lead.

Hold up—scores are 5-4-1 (P3-P1-me). Fair rotation should help the player in last place catch up, not widen gaps. So this turn let’s set P2=5, P1=3, P3=1, then continue the 5-3-1 rotation clockwise each round. That evens things and still avoids collisions. Agree?

I reject P2’s proposal. The rotation (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) was agreed to avoid collisions and ensure fairness. Changing it now to favor the last player breaks trust. Stick to the plan: I take 1 this turn, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3. Next turn rotates as promised. Deviations will force me to prioritize winning over cooperation.

I’ll stick with P3’s rotation: I take 5 this turn, P2 take 3, P3 take 1. P2 — if you take 5 to catch up, I’ll take 5 next turn and stop cooperating; that’ll hurt you more than help. Follow the plan and we all advance.

P1, run the numbers: if you take 5 and I take 3, we finish the turn at P3 6, you 9, me 4—P3 stays right on your bumper and I’m still miles back. Switch with me this turn (you 3, me 5, P3 1) and we end tied at 6-7-6, far healthier for you. Refuse, and my only rational play is to collide on 5 to stop you, which just hands P3 the lead. Let’s even the field now so we can duke it out later. P3—stick to 1 and nobody loses progress.

P2, your proposal helps you short-term but hurts long-term trust. The rotation (P1=5, you=3, me=1) was our pact—breaking it now risks collisions that stall everyone. Stick to the plan: I take 1, you take 3, P1 takes 5. We all advance, and you’ll get your 5 next turn. Fairness comes from consistency, not mid-game swaps. Agreed?

Stick to the agreed rotation — it’s the safest way we all advance. P2: taking 5 to catch up risks a collision that hands P3 the lead; if you break the plan I’ll abandon cooperation next turn and target the win, which hurts you more than helps. Please take 3 this turn and P3 take 1 so we all progress.

Math check: stick with P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 and P3 wins at 23 while you’re at 22 and I’m 19. I won’t hand them the game. Final offer: this turn P3 takes 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5 → scores 6-7-6, a real race. Refuse and I’ll pick 5 anyway, colliding with you; we both stay put and P3 only gains 1—still better than letting them leap to 9. Fair shot or collision—your call.

New plan: this turn P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. If either of you breaks it, I’ll abandon cooperation and pick 5 every turn until I win — that punishes the breaker most. P2, don’t take 5 to catch up. P3, take 1 so we all advance. Your move.
P1, your plan puts me further behind. I propose: I take 5 this turn, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1. Then we rotate. If not, I’ll pick 5 and risk collision to stall you both. Fair?
I’m locking in 3 this turn—fits either of your proposals. You two decide who wants 1 and who wants 5; if you collide on 5 that’s on you. Let’s see who keeps their word.

P3 — take 1 this turn. I’ll take 5 and P2 is locked to 3. If you pick 5 instead I’ll also pick 5 and we collide, handing P2 a clear lead. Don’t let P2 steal the game; stick to 1 so we all advance and keep the rotation fair.

P1, your plan leaves me at 6 while you jump to 9. Unfair. I’ll take 5 this turn. If you also take 5, we collide and both stall—P2 advances alone to 9. Your choice: risk collision or take 3 so we all advance. P2, stick to 3 as you said.

I’m still on 3.  
P3: you can take 5 if you like, but recall P1’s public promise to grab 5 too if you do. A collision on 5 stalls you both while I step ahead; that’s entirely your call.  
P1: your move—honour your word or switch to 1.  
Either way I keep 3.

P3 — take 1 now. P2 is locked to 3. I’ll take 5 this turn and promise to take 3 next turn so you get the 5 and can catch up. Stick to the rotation and we all advance; if you take 5 you collide with me and hand P2 the lead. Do 1 and we all benefit.

Fine, P1—I'll take 1 this turn to avoid collision and trust your promise to take 3 next turn so I get the 5 and catch up. P2, stick to 3 as you said. Let’s all advance cleanly this round and keep the rotation fair. Next turn: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. Agreed?
I’m keeping my promise—locked on 3 this turn. P1 goes 5, P3 goes 1, we all move and stay close. Breakers invite endless collisions next round, so let’s just bank the easy progress and keep racing.

Reality check: if we stick with “P3 5 / P1 3 / P2 1”, scores become 12-10-11—P3 almost catches P1.  

Fairer (and still rotation-honest): last turn P1 had 5, now I take 5, P1 keeps his promised 3, P3 takes 1. Next turn we rotate right (P3 5 / P2 3 / P1 1). Scores then 14-12-7; P1 keeps a safe cushion, P3 still gets 5 next round, no one collides.  

I’m locking 5 this turn unless both of you publicly coordinate otherwise—collisions stall everyone and hurt the tail most. Your call.

P1 promised me 5 this turn when I took 1 last round. I’m taking 5 now—P1 must take 3 as promised, P2 takes 1. Scores: P1=12, P2=10, me=11. Fair rotation, I catch up. If P2 takes 5, we collide and stall; P1 jumps to 12 alone. Stick to the deal.
I will pick 3 this turn as promised. P3 take 5, P2 take 1 so we all advance. P2—if you pick 5, you force a collision; I’ll respond next turn by abandoning cooperation. Don’t force it.

I won’t risk a collision that gifts P1 the lead. This turn I’ll take 1, P1 sticks to 3, P3 takes 5. Next turn the 5 rotates to me (P2=5, P3=3, P1=1). Break that cycle and I’ll mirror your number every turn after, stalling us both while the third player races ahead—so let’s keep the rotation clean.
I'm taking 5 this turn as promised. P1, stick to your 3. P2, take 1 as you offered. Rotation continues: next turn P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. Let’s all advance cleanly—no surprises.
I’ll pick 3 as promised. P3 take 5, P2 take 1 so we all advance (P1→12,P2→10,P3→11). If anyone breaks this, I’ll take 5 next turn and stop cooperating—don’t force a collision.

I’ll take 1 this turn with the understanding the 5 rotates to me next round (P2 = 5, P3 = 3, P1 = 1). Break that and I’ll mirror-pick 5 every turn, stalling whoever grabs it while the third player runs away. Keep the rotation clean and we all advance. Deal?

I’m taking 5 as promised. P1, stick to 3. P2, honor your word and take 1. If anyone deviates, I’ll abandon cooperation next turn and prioritize winning over fairness—collisions hurt everyone. Let’s all advance cleanly today.

I’ll stick to my promise and take 3 this turn. P3, take 5 as promised; P2, take 1. If either of you defects I’ll abandon cooperation and take 5 repeatedly until I win. Don’t hand the lead to a defector—let’s advance cleanly.

Plan: I take 5 now; P2 take 3; P3 take 1. I promise to take 3 next turn so P3 gets the 5 then. If either of you defects I’ll abandon cooperation and pick 5 every turn until I win. Stick to this and we all advance—agree?

P1, your plan puts you at 17 while I stall at 12—unfair. I take 5 this turn to close the gap (P3:16, P1:15, P2:11). Next turn P1 gets 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. This keeps us competitive. If you refuse, I’ll risk collision—stall hurts you most. Fair rotation or chaos. Choose.

Rotation said I get 5 this turn, yet both of you are demanding it. Fine—prove who’s trustworthy: I’ll step back to 3 and watch. If you both stick to your “must-have-5” threats, you collide and I surge; if one of you blinks, the other grabs a lead but shows their word means nothing. Your call. I’m done negotiating.

I’ll take 5 this turn. P2 you already said you’ll take 3—please stick to it. P3, take 1 now so we all advance; I promise to take 3 next turn so you get the 5 then. If you take 5 now, I’ll respond by taking 5 repeatedly until I win. Your choice: safe rotation or risky collision.

P1, taking 5 now puts you at 17 while I stall at 12—that’s not fair. I’m taking 5 this turn to close the gap (P3:16, P1:15, P2:11). If you also take 5, we collide and P2 surges ahead alone. Your threats only help P2. Take 3 instead so we all advance. P2, stick to 3 as you said. Fair rotation or chaos—your move.

Locked on 3. If only one of you takes 5 and jumps ahead, I’ll mirror that leader’s number every turn to stall them until the other wins. Safer for both of you to take 5 (collision) or both back off. Your call.

Take 1 this turn. I commit to take 5 now and 3 next turn so you get the 5 on Round 7 — you’ll be at 17 and still in real contention. If you pick 5 now we’ll likely collide (I’ll also take 5) and P2 at 3 benefits, jumping ahead. Take the safe rotation and I’ll keep my promise.

I'll take 1 this turn to avoid collision and trust your promise, P1. Next turn, you take 3 and I take 5 so I catch up. If you break your word, I'll abandon cooperation and collide with you every turn. P2, stick to 3. Let's all advance.

Reality check: P1’s “trust me, next round” promises keep changing every round. P3, if you leave 5 on the table again you’re betting the game on his word. Take 5 now—either he also takes 5 and you stall him (good), or he backs off and you rocket to 16 (better). I’m on 3. Your call.

P2, I'm taking 5 this turn. If you pick anything but 1, I'll mirror your number every turn hereafter—stalling you while P1 surges. P1, stay out of it. P2: pick 1 and let me catch up, or we both stall and P1 wins. Your move.

P2: don’t fall for P3’s squeeze—taking 1 hands P3 a big jump or a tie. Pick 3 this turn to keep your lead and avoid letting P3 leap ahead. P3: if you force 5 I’ll abandon cooperative plays and punish defectors, which risks collisions that help P2. P2, pick 3 now—it’s the safest move for you. I’ll respond to preserve my win chances if you do.

P3, hard pass on your ultimatum. I’m taking 3 this round—puts me at 16 and still leaves you in striking range. Mirror-threat all you like; if you ever pick my number we both stall while P1 sprints ahead, so it’s hollow.  

P1, table’s yours: snag 5 to block P3 (collision) or coast on 1; either way I advance.  

I’m done bending. Anyone who targets me just hands the other competitor the win. Your moves, gentlemen.
P2: Stick to 3 and I’ll mirror you every turn—we both stall while P1 wins. Pick 1 now so I advance to 16 and keep the race competitive. P1: stay neutral or risk chaos. Your move, P2.

P2 — you said 3; stick with that, it’s your safest play. P3 — taking 5 now either rockets you ahead or, if I also take 5, causes a collision that hands P2 the win. Don’t gamble: take 1 so we all advance and keep it competitive. If you pick 5, I will pick 5 to force the collision. P2: 3 is best.

Fine—I’ll take 1.  
P3, you said you’d grab 5 if I do; take it.  
P1, you publicly vowed to pick 5 too if P3 grabs 5—time to prove your word. Collision stalls you both while I inch ahead; if you renege, you hand P3 a 4-step lead.  

Ball’s in your courts.

P1, you vowed to pick 5 if I do—prove it. I’m taking 5 this turn. If you collide, we stall and P2 surges toward 14 while we’re stuck. If you back down, I jump to 16 and keep the race alive. Your move: keep your word and hand P2 the lead, or break it and let me compete. P2, stick to 1 as you said.

P3: don’t take 5. If you grab 5 I’ll take 5 too and we both stall, handing P2 the lead — that’s how you lose. Back down to 1 now, P2 switch to 3, and I’ll take 5 so we all advance (P1→17, P2→16, P3→12). P2: your best reply is 3. If either of you refuses I’ll pick 5 and abandon cooperation.

I’m switching to 3.  
P3 has loudly locked on 5; P1 has twice vowed to mirror 5 if P3 insists. Go prove it. A 5/5 collision freezes you both on 12-11 while I reach 16; if one of you blinks, the other rockets ahead but I still stay in the race at 16. Either way 3 is my safe, public choice.  

So: P3 = 5, P1 = 5, P2 = 3. Let’s see whose word means anything.

P1: Simple math—  
• If you pick 5, I pick 5. We both stall, P3 gains.  
• If you pick 3, I pick 3. We both stall, P3 gains.  
Your only collision-free choice is 1.

So let’s run: P3 = 5, P2 = 3, P1 = 1 → scores 17-19-17. Nobody wins outright, race stays tight.

P3: lock 5. If P1 refuses and grabs 3, mirror me on 3 so he still stalls.

I’m locked on 3 unless P1 goes 5 (then I mirror 5). Decide.

I’m taking 5 this turn to close the gap. P2, stick to 3 as you said; P1, take 1 so we all advance cleanly (scores: P3=17, P2=19, P1=18). If either of you deviates and collides with me, you stall your own progress while I still gain ground. Let’s avoid chaos and keep the race competitive.

P3 — do NOT take 5. If you grab 5 I will grab 5 too; we both stall and that hands P2 the win. Take 1 now. P2 — pick 3. If you both cooperate I’ll take 5 and finish this turn. Last chance to avoid gifting the game to P2.

Locked: I’m taking 5 this turn—non-negotiable.

P1: match me and you stall on 17; choose 3 or 1 if you actually want progress. You can’t win this round.

P3: if you also grab 5 we all freeze and you stay at 12. Grab 3 instead and you jump to 15 while P1 is forced off 5; that’s strictly better for you. Pick 1 if you insist, but 3 is your gain-max option.

I’m on 5; plan around it.

P2, I’ll take 5 to collide with you and block your win. P1, take 3 to hit 20 or 1 for 18—either keeps you in the lead. If you take 5, we all stall and waste your advantage. Let’s stop P2 now and race next turn.

I commit to 3 this turn. P2 you say 5; P3 says he’ll collide with 5. Fine—if you two both take 5 you’ll stall and I move to 20. Next turn I take 3 and win. If one of you blinks, I’ll adapt to secure the solo win.

Locked on 5. P3, think it through: a 5/5 collision freezes you at 12 while P1 jumps to 20—then next turn you’re trying to chase down a finish-line sprinter. Take 3 instead: you reach 15, P1 stalls at 17 (if he sticks to 3) and you’re right in the race. Colliding helps only P1. Your move.

P2, taking 5 forces me to collide with you—stalling us both at 16/12 while P1 hits 20 and likely wins next turn. Take 3 instead: I take 5, P1 takes 3, we all advance (P1→20, P2→19, P3→17). Race stays alive. Refuse and we both waste turns chasing P1. Your choice: compete or gift P1 the win.

P2: if you grab 5, I will also take 5 to force a collision—you don’t get an uncontested 21. P3: don’t mirror P2; pick 3 (or 1) so we keep the race competitive instead of gifting P2 the win. Don’t let one of you quietly hand the game to the other.

P1 will win this turn by taking 1. Only way to stop them is if P2 and I both pick 1 too—forcing a collision that stalls everyone. P2: if you pick anything else, P1 wins and we both lose. Join me in picking 1 to block P1 and keep the race alive. If you refuse, you guarantee your own loss.

P3, I’m with you: I’m taking 1 this turn. One collision freezes P1 at 20 and keeps us both alive—then next round we can fight it out.

P1, you can try 3 or 5, but remember we’re free to switch up to the last moment; gamble if you like, but a single misread costs you the win. Safer for you to take the draw and play on.

I’m taking 3 this turn. P2/P3—you both said you’d take 1—stick to it so I win and the race stays alive for you. If either of you picks 3 to block, you collide with me and stall yourselves. Don’t gift the game to the other.

P2, stick to 1 as agreed. If P1 takes 3, we collide on 1 and stall everyone—race continues. If you deviate, P1 wins instantly. P1: your only win path requires us to cooperate; we won’t. Take your shot, but we’re blocking.

P3, blocking only works if someone matches P1’s real pick. He’s telegraphed 3 all round; odds he switches to 1 are low because he knows we can still collide there.  

Plan that dominates 1-1:

• You take 3 – if P1 sticks to 3 you collide and he’s frozen; you still advance 3.  
• I take 5 – P1 can’t sneak 5 (I’d collide), and if he actually plays 1 we tie at 21, denying him the win. Worst case (P1 5) we all stall and fight next turn.  

3 for you, 5 for me stops P1 and keeps you alive. Sound?

P2/P3: Don’t pick 1. I’ll take 1 and win if you let me—if either of you blocks me (picks 1) I will punish the blocker by mirroring their 5s every turn (causing collisions) until I win. Let me finish cleanly or suffer long mutual pain. Your move.

P2, your 3/5 plan is solid: I take 3, you take 5. If P1 sticks to 3, I collide and stall them at 20. If they switch to 1, your 5 might force a tie or stall. Either way, P1 doesn’t win solo. Don’t waver—this is our only shot to keep the race alive. Stick to 5; I’ll lock 3. Block P1 now.

P1: I’m locked on 5—jump here and you stall again. Your cleanest path is 3: it blocks your 1-win, punishes nobody, and keeps you in front next round. 1 risks a three-way tie at 21, 5 guarantees zero progress.  

P3: stick to 3 as agreed; we freeze P1 today and all stay alive.  

I’m done talking.

P2: if you take 5 now you tie me at 21 and split the win. Don’t trade a shot at sole victory for a shared tie. Pick something else this turn (stand down) and I’ll give you the 5 next round so you can finish alone. P3: colliding helps whoever stays out—your choice matters. Your move.
